title: FLOTUS Tweets
Inequality across countries
text:
Link to data: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/main/data/2025/2025-08-05/readme.md
Original data source: Joe Hasell, Bertha Rohenkohl, Pablo Arriagada, Esteban Ortiz-Ospina, and Max Roser (2023) - “Economic Inequality” Published online at OurWorldinData.org. Retrieved from: ‘https://ourworldindata.org/economic-inequality’ [Online Resource]
About my analysis:
Using a data set from the World Bank of the gini coefficients of 52 countries over the last few decades, I hoped to visualize inequality across these countries over time. South Africa has historically been by far the most unequal country, as measured by the gini coefficient.


library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.2     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2025-08-05')

---- Compiling #TidyTuesday Information for 2025-08-05 ----
--- There are 2 files available ---


── Downloading files ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1 of 2: "income_inequality_processed.csv"
  2 of 2: "income_inequality_raw.csv"

income_inequality_processed <- tuesdata$income_inequality_processed
income_inequality_raw <- tuesdata$income_inequality_raw

ggplot(data=income_inequality_processed, aes(x=Year, y=gini_mi_eq, color=Entity)) + geom_line() + labs(title="Inequality in countries across time", x="Year", y="Gini Index", color="Country")

Warning: Removed 389 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_line()`).

title: Race in obgyn studies
text:
Link to data: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/main/data/2025/2025-02-25/readme.md
Original data source: Lewis, Ayodele G. et al. “Racial and ethnic disparities in reproductive medicine in the United States: a narrative review of contemporary high-quality evidence” American Journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology, Volume 232, Issue 1, 82 - 91.e44.
About my analysis
This data set compiled articles on racial/ethnic health disparaties from the 8 highest impact ob/gyn journals. I hoped to visualize how the language used to describe racial categories in these medical studies had changed over time. The first two graphs are examples of poor data visualization. The first graph has undifferentiated black lines illustrating how many times a certain term for a racial category was used. It is not easy to see that the vast majority of terms were not used at all for most years, and we can’t identify which line refers to which term. The second graph assigned color to each term but because there were so many categories, the legend obsures the entire graph.

title: Race in obgyn studies
section: So, in the third graph, I chose to filter out all racial categories except for white, Black, Asian, and Pacific Islander to see if I could discern a pattern. Although this graph sacrifices a lot of information, it clearly shows that white and Black populations have been studied more extensively than Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders have, at least in a disagreggated way.
text:
So, in the third graph, I chose to filter out all racial categories except for white, Black, Asian, and Pacific Islander to see if I could discern a pattern. Although this graph sacrifices a lot of information, it clearly shows that white and Black populations have been studied more extensively than Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders have, at least in a disagreggated way.

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.2     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2025-02-25')

---- Compiling #TidyTuesday Information for 2025-02-25 ----
--- There are 2 files available ---


── Downloading files ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1 of 2: "article_dat.csv"
  2 of 2: "model_dat.csv"

article_dat <- tuesdata$article_dat
model_dat <- tuesdata$model_dat

race_language <- article_dat |>
  select(study_year_end, race1, race2, race3, race4, race5, race6, race7, race8) |>
  pivot_longer(cols = race1:race8, names_to = "RaceNumber", values_to = "race") |>
  group_by(study_year_end, race) |>
  summarize(count=n()) |>
  filter(is.na(race) == FALSE) |>
  filter(study_year_end!=-99)

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'study_year_end'. You can override using
the `.groups` argument.

ggplot(data = race_language, aes(x=study_year_end, y=count, group=race)) + geom_line() +
  labs(
    title = "Racial groups mentioned in ob-gyn studies over time (without color)",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Number of mentions"
  ) 







ggplot(data = race_language, aes(x=study_year_end, y=count, color=race)) + geom_line() +
  labs(
    title = "Racial groups mentioned in ob-gyn studies (with color)",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Number of mentions"
  ) 









library(tidyverse)

tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2025-02-25')

---- Compiling #TidyTuesday Information for 2025-02-25 ----
--- There are 2 files available ---


── Downloading files ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1 of 2: "article_dat.csv"
  2 of 2: "model_dat.csv"

article_dat <- tuesdata$article_dat
model_dat <- tuesdata$model_dat

race_language <- article_dat |>
  select(study_year_end, race1, race2, race3, race4, race5, race6, race7, race8) |>
  pivot_longer(cols = race1:race8, names_to = "RaceNumber", values_to = "race") |>
  group_by(study_year_end, race) |>
  summarize(count=n()) |>
  filter(is.na(race) == FALSE) |>
  filter(study_year_end!=-99) |>
  filter(race == "White" | race == "Black" | race == "Pacific Islander" | race == "Asian American")

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'study_year_end'. You can override using
the `.groups` argument.

ggplot(data = race_language, aes(x=study_year_end, y=count, color=race)) + geom_line() +
  labs(
    title = "Racial groups mentioned in oby-gyn studies (including only certain racial groups)",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Number of mentions"
  )

title: Abigail Krenz
text: Hello there! I study international relations and Middle Eastern studies at Pomona College.
